title.narrative: Shelter And Infrastructure Support For Non-Camp Refugees

description.narrative:
The purpose of this project is to provide for shelter needs of the most vulnerable refugee families and thereby establish practices that can be replicated, and also to support the provision of basic WASH services in communities under strain. The project specifically addresses the limited capacity of municipalities to meet increased WASH demands in communities under strain. The target populations are refugee families benefitting from shelter support and municipalities, as well as host communities and refugee families benefitting from better WASH services.
The project seeks to identify real priorities through consulting affected communities applying the house-to-house surveys and local focus group discussions; interventions will be designed and implemented to meet these priorities. The experience gained and lessons learnt from the first phase will help build up a base for a more comprehensive project with sustainable impacts. The current project seeks to improve the living conditions (shelter WASH) in accommodations rented by refugee families in the three KR governorates using a combination of methods as required. The self-help procedure will be applied to mobilize a quick start of work and ensure simultaneous independent progress. An NGO will be employed to manage this process. The self-help will create a win-win situation where the house owner replaces the contractor and employs tenants as labor (if they are capable). Both parties will benefit from the upgrade. For owners unable to undertake the construction management, the NGO will provide that. Habitat will do the assessment, monitoring and make sure the evaluations are correct and quality of work is up to standard.
Within the self-help method for improving shelters, the house owner is given either cash or coupons to buy building materials for fixing is house and pay for labor as well. The cash is provided in installments (two or more) based on the type of upgrade and level of completion. The NGO will hand out the installments based on monitoring reports and provide technical assistance for implementing the job. Habitat will be monitoring the implementation, providing technical assistance and quality control.
The proposed solutions include a range of affordable shelter support options, eg cash for owner driven improvements on host houses, basic improvements of incomplete houses being rented to allow basic appropriate shelter, etc. The possible partners are local NGO Kurds; basic services directorates of Duhok, Erbil and Suleymaniah municipalities, Governorates and Governors of Duhok, Erbil and Suleymaniah, UNHCR, non-camp Shelter/WASH working group. UN-Habitat will incorporate lessons learnt into the non-camp Shelter/WASH strategy.
It is expected that the number of assisted families will be as follows: Duhok 225 families, Erbil 160 in Sulymania 48 families (total 433 families in three governorates). The amount allocated for each family will be around $1600 on average allowing more sustainable rehabilitation to be undertaken.
As for WASH projects, the municipalities in KR are engaged in numerous upgrading projects and are in need of support to improve their service delivery and bridge the existing funding gap. Habitat will engage in supporting municipalities in implementing their projects in areas with high concentrations of Syrian refugee families. The support will be in the form of procurement, technical assistance encouraging coordination between service provision directorates and direct implementation.

description.narrative: number of agreements signed between house owner and local authorities.

comment.narrative: the agreement for house rehabilitation that Habitat is providing to the house rented by the Syrian refugee families. this is a document signed between the house owner and local authorities that lists the construction items and the owner's approval for executing them on the condition that the Syrian refugee family remains in that place without increasing the rent or threat of eviction beyond the set time frame.
